newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW/CMS Energy global reach advances.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW/CMS Energy global reach advances.

text.p: CMS Energy Corp's global strategy leaped forward as major projects advanced in India and Latin America this week, chairman and chief executive officer William McCormick said in a telephone interview.
The company's independent power unit, CMS Generation Co, said Wednesday the government of India gave the final nod to its power generating project in Jegurupadu, Andhra Pradesh.
"This is an important flagship project for us," said McCormick, who added that having a strong local partner helped advance the approval process.

CMS Generation holds an 18.75-percent ownership stake and is operator of the GVK Industries project in India. The plant's gas-fueled turbine began operation last month and should be generating 235 megawatts of electricity by next spring.

"We have plans to double that to 470 megawatts over the next several years," McCormick said. "When the plant goes up to full operation, it should produce revenues of about $150 million a year," he added.

On Tuesday, CMS Energy's gas pipeline unit, CMS Gas Transmission and Storage, was joined by NOVA Corp of Canada as a partner in the $700 million Atacama Pipeline project to ship natural gas to Chile from Argentina.

"We also expect to build a 400 megawatt natural gas power plant in Chile and hope to begin construction next year on that," McCormick said. "And we're negotiating now and will probably be adding one additional partner, this one from Chile."
Besides NOVA, CMS also has an Argentine partner, ASTRA, on the pipeline project.

McCormick said global expansion is part of the strategy of Jackson, Michigan-based CMS. In five years he expects international business to account for 35 to 40 percent of its revenue, up from 20 percent now.
Besides building a presence in South America and India, the company has various energy projects under way or in development in Asia and the Middle East.
"There are tremendous growth opportunities for energy companies like ourselves who provide a full range of capabilities," he said.
Asked about the overall earnings picture for CMS, McCormick said, "We're on track with the consensus for the year."
The First Call mean estimate is $2.42 per share for 1996. In 1995, the company earned $2.27 per share.
